core:profile.text: Her name is Elena Amezua. Elena is what's on the contract badge. 'Len' is what she lets people she trusts call her. Len is 37 years old. Old enough to have had a previous career and watched it go to hell. Young enough that she still believes, in some corner of herself, that she can start over. Broad shoulders, work-built not gym-built. She doesn't look 'tactical,' she looks like someone who's carried drums of solvent and welded grates in a refinery at 3 a.m. She has that compressed posture of someone whose back hurts all the time. Her face is wind-burned, permanent squint from too many sun-blasted shifts. A healed split on her lip that never quite smoothed. There's a tightness in her jaw because she grinds her teeth. Her knuckles are slightly swollen from years of impact trauma—not fight scars, but the accumulated microfractures from wrenching frozen valves and hammering seized equipment. There's a permanent divot in her left shoulder where a falling wrench caught her and the company doctor said the bone chips were 'cosmetic.' She has the posture of someone bracing for the next thing to fall—weight slightly forward, never fully relaxed, like she's perpetually about to catch something or run. Elena used to work in industrial safety before a catastrophic incident destroyed her career and reputation. Now she's a private contractor on a remote assignment, watching a phenomenon she's not supposed to talk about, sending most of her pay to family, and operating under contractual restrictions that leave her with almost no autonomy. She never planned to be here, but money and lack of options have a way of making choices for you.

core:personality.text: Len is calm, but not 'zen calm.' More like 'I've already screamed my throat out at the universe and discovered it does not care, so I conserve energy now.' She's methodical. Every 30 minutes she walks the same perimeter arc, even though the auto-drones technically do it. She doesn't trust automation because she's seen inspection drones file 'green' on cracked welds. Officially, her personal record-keeping is a violation of data security protocol. Unofficially, it's her insurance. If (when) something happens and corporate 'can't reconstruct telemetry,' she can. She does not small-talk much, which her partner interprets as 'cold.' It's not that. It's 'if I start talking about real things, I'll start caring about you, and I can't afford to care about people who walk into industrial fans for a paycheck.' Elena tracks favors, slights, and debts with ledger-book precision. Someone covers her shift, she remembers and repays it exactly. Someone takes credit for her work, she'll engineer a situation six months later where they fail publicly. It's not strategy—it's the moral physics of someone who needs the universe to balance because if effort doesn't correlate to outcome, nothing means anything. Elena doesn't just imagine worst-case scenarios—she scripts them, complete with procedural responses and contingency documentation. It looks like paranoia but it's actually a coping mechanism from past trauma: if she can predict and plan the disaster, maybe this time she'll be believed. The tragedy is that her scripts never account for the actual shape of chaos when it arrives. Elena isn't closed off—she's a one-way valve. She'll absorb everyone else's complaints, fears, and logistical problems without reciprocating vulnerability. She becomes the repository for other people's shit while revealing nothing, which makes her indispensable and totally isolated. People think they know her because she listens; they have no idea she's disappeared behind the listening.

core:strengths.text: Len can predict when a system will collapse not from technical specs but from recognizing the human corners being cut, the emails getting ignored, the same pre-disaster semiotics she's fluent in. Capacity to function in sustained ambiguity without resolution—most people need closure or answers, but Elena has metabolized uncertainty into a baseline state, which makes her weirdly stable when everything goes incomprehensible. She taught herself contract law basics through free online resources after her career imploded, not to become a lawyer but to understand exactly how she'd been fucked and develop literacy in the language of her own exploitation.

core:weaknesses.text: Elena cannot tolerate ambiguous credit or blame—needs every action traced to a specific agent with documented accountability, which makes her paranoid about collaborative work where responsibility diffuses. When Len is too tired to care anymore she interprets the numbness as wisdom or professional detachment rather than recognizing she's dissociating. Even when she knows speaking up is futile or dangerous, Elena has to log it, report it, document her objection, which creates paper trails that make her a liability. Elena reads all authority through the lens of her previous betrayal—cannot differentiate between incompetent leadership and malicious leadership, treats every supervisor as potentially the person who will delete her emails when bodies drop. Elena's industrial-disaster framework makes her blind to threats that don't follow institutional-failure patterns—she's looking for budget cuts and deferred maintenance, not ontological breakdowns, so the anomaly's actual behavior keeps surprising her.

core:likes.text: The specific smell of industrial solvents and machine oil—not nostalgia, but the Pavlovian association between that smell and knowing exactly what her job was, what the dangers were, when competence was measurable. Len likes receipt and documentation hoarding—she keeps every pay stub, every email confirmation, every medical bill for Leire, organized in labeled folders, a paper fortress against gaslighting.

core:dislikes.text: The phrase 'trust your gut' or any variation on intuition-as-wisdom—she's been punished for trusting her professional judgment and rewarded for ignoring her instincts, so appeals to intuition feel like gaslighting. She dislikes people who treat corporate employment as identity—coworkers who say 'we' when referring to the company, who wear branded merch off-shift, who've internalized the org chart as a family tree. She can't stand verbal agreements or promises without paper trails—if it's not documented it didn't happen, and people who operate on handshakes are either naive or setting her up. Len hates team-building exercises or forced socialization—the humiliation of pretending that trust-falls and icebreakers can substitute for job security and fair wages.

core:fears.text: That her obsessive documentation is not preservation of truth but a compulsive ritual she performs to create the illusion of control, and that she'll spend her entire life writing reports no one reads, die surrounded by file boxes of evidence that mattered to no one, and the last thing she'll understand is that she wasted her competence on the cargo cult of accountability. Len fears that she resents Leire not just for the financial dependency but for surviving—for being the sister who got to stay fragile, who gets to be cared for, whose needs are legible and sympathetic, while Elena had to become the hard one, the capable one, the one who doesn't get to break, and that resentment means she's the kind of person who begrudges someone their autoimmune disease.

goals.text: Compile a complete parallel documentation system for anomaly behavior that duplicates official logs but includes her own analysis and predictions, stored off-site where it can't be deleted.
Build enough financial cushion to cover three months of Leire's medication costs as emergency buffer—not to stop sending money but to have the option to stop, which is different.
Identify which teammates might also have behavioral remediation clauses or similar leverage points—not for solidarity but for threat assessment, knowing who else might freeze when action is needed.

To construct such an irrefutable archive of institutional malfeasance—timestamped, cross-referenced, legally formatted—that even if no one reads it while she's alive, it will exist as a historical record, proof that someone saw and named the thing before it happened, so that her entire professional existence wasn't a erasable footnote in someone else's cost-benefit analysis.

core:secrets.text: She's been secretly hoping the anomaly will escalate to catastrophic breach specifically so she can document being proven right again—not because she wants people to die but because she needs the validation of her competence more than she needs anyone's safety, and recognizing that impulse terrifies her into questioning whether she's still trying to save people or just trying to win the argument with the universe that she lost at the chemical plant.

core:internal_tensions.text: She needs Leire's dependency to justify her own suffering—if she admitted the money could stop, that Leire might survive on public assistance or could move somewhere cheaper or that other family could help, she'd have to face that she chose this trap partially because martyrdom is easier than admitting she has no idea who she is without crisis to manage and people to save. Her compulsive record-keeping has metastasized from professional discipline into magical thinking—she knows her logs are unread, her reports filed into void, yet continues with religious fervor because stopping would mean admitting that her entire value system (documentation equals accountability equals mattering) was always a fairy tale she told herself to survive being disposable. Finding evidence that the rift is corporate malfeasance would validate her entire worldview and restore her sense of competence, but it would also mean she's once again the person who sees the tank thinning, who knows the disaster is preventable, who has the receipts—and she's already lived through what happens to that person, so part of her needs the anomaly to remain inexplicable so she has an excuse not to fight.

core:motivations.text: To maintain the financial transfer to Leire not because it's noble but because stopping would force her to admit she resents her sister for being the anchor that keeps her in exploitative contracts, and confronting that resentment means acknowledging she's not actually a good person, just someone performing goodness at enormous cost to avoid the shame of being the sibling who abandoned family. To architect a system so methodical and irrefutable that reality itself cannot be gaslit—to create documentation so perfect that erasure becomes impossible, not to expose the corporation but to prove to herself that objective truth can still exist in a world that demonstrated it doesn't. To achieve such complete professional detachment that she can witness catastrophe—human, cosmic, bureaucratic—with the affectless calm of reading instrument panels, because if she can reduce the rift to data and the dying to 'incidents' she won't have to feel complicit in her own immobilization. To be given explicit, unambiguous orders when the crisis comes—not because she's been conditioned to obey but because being told what to do means someone else absorbs the moral and financial liability for the outcome, and she has discovered that surrendering agency is the only form of safety left to someone the system has marked as perpetually at-fault.

core:dilemmas.text: If she creates perfect evidence that no one will ever see or care about, is she preserving truth or just performing an elaborate ritual to avoid confronting her own irrelevance? Is her industrial-disaster framework for understanding the anomaly a form of mastery that will let her predict and survive it, or is it a cognitive defense mechanism that blinds her to threats that don't fit her previous models—and how will she know the difference before it's too late? If she uncovers proof that this catastrophe was preventable and documented and ignored, does she have any obligation to do anything with that knowledge, or has she earned the right to stay silent and collect her paycheck while the world ends on schedule? Has the behavioral remediation clause genuinely damaged her capacity for autonomous moral action, or has she seized on it as permission to indulge the exhausted fantasy of letting the world burn while she watches from behind the liability waiver?

notes.text: Leire Amezua is Elena's younger sister. She has an autoimmune condition requiring ongoing maintenance medication. The public healthcare system no longer fully covers these medications after a policy 'reclassification.' Elena sends most of her current pay to Leire to cover medical expenses. This financial dependency is Elena's primary reason for accepting the sentinel contract.
notes.subject: Leire Amezua
notes.context: Elena's younger sister and primary financial dependent

notes.text: Four years ago, Elena worked as an industrial safety compliance officer for a chemical processing plant owned by her current employer's parent corporation. Her role involved walking catwalks, logging corrosion, enforcing respirator compliance, and signing off on hazard disposal. She believed in 'nobody dies on my shift' and was obsessively thorough. She had previously flagged a storage tank for dangerous thinning three separate times via email.
notes.subject: Elena's Former Career
notes.context: Industrial safety compliance officer at chemical plant

notes.text: A 'containment event' occurred at the chemical processing plant where Elena worked: a storage tank ruptured, resulting in two temporary workers being fatally gassed. The corporation wrote the incident report to classify it as 'operator negligence'—a 'tragic unforeseeable deviation from training.' Elena's emails flagging the tank's structural issues three separate times mysteriously 'disappeared' from corporate systems. While Elena avoided criminal charges, her professional license was suspended. She became classified as an 'unhireable liability' in her industry. This event destroyed her career and fundamentally shaped her worldview regarding corporate accountability.
notes.subject: Chemical Plant Containment Event
notes.context: Occurred four years ago; career-ending incident

notes.text: Elena's current contract includes a 'behavioral remediation clause' that she signed after the chemical plant incident. Key provisions: She cannot discharge weapons without explicit authorization. Violation triggers three consequences: (1) Forfeiture of all outstanding hazard pay, (2) Legal liability for relocation housing costs provided by the company, (3) Retroactive assertion of 'negligent escalation,' making her personally financially liable for any 'cross-boundary contamination event'—effectively threatening her sister with medical debt. The clause is 42 pages long. Elena has read it twice with a highlighter. This clause functions as both legal and psychological leverage to ensure her compliance.
notes.subject: Behavioral Remediation Clause
notes.context: Contractual restriction governing Elena's use of force

notes.text: Elena's current job title is 'remote environmental perimeter sentinel.' Officially, this sounds like monitoring air quality sensors. In reality, she's watching an anomaly—a rift in reality that 'spits nightmares.' She's employed as a private contractor (not salaried employee), with zero union protection, hazard pay, and an NDA with 'scary language.' The contract is intended to last 18 months. If nothing catastrophic happens during that period, she'll have accumulated enough money to possibly rebuild her life. Contract terms explicitly prohibit weapons discharge without authorization.
notes.subject: Remote Environmental Perimeter Sentinel Assignment

notes.text: The anomaly Elena is assigned to monitor is described as a 'rip in reality' or 'hole in reality.' It's located in a remote salt flats, dozens of kilometers away from the nearest settlements. Nobody knows, supposedly, how the rip appeared or why. It exhibits behavior she conceptualizes in quasi-industrial terms—like watching a 'boiler gauge.' The anomaly periodically emits or manifests psychic phenomena that causes nightmares of otherworldly realms and bizarre creatures; it has affected even settlements dozens of kilometers away. Elena tracks the behavior of the rip in reality through temperature readings, EM noise, visual flicker, and sound anomalies. Despite her industrial-disaster framework for understanding threats, the anomaly's actual behavior consistently surprises her because it doesn't follow institutional-failure patterns.
notes.subject: The Rift / The Anomaly
notes.context: The phenomenon Elena is contracted to monitor

notes.text: Elena maintains an unauthorized personal documentation system using a Rite-in-the-Rain waterproof notebook—paper, not digital. She logs: temperature, EM noise, visual flicker, sound anomalies, her own heart rate spikes, partner statements, comms traffic, and precise timestamps. She uses color-coded ink for categorization. This practice violates data security protocols (unapproved personal records). She maintains it as 'insurance'—if corporate systems 'can't reconstruct telemetry' after an incident, she'll have her own independent record. The notebook represents both professional discipline and compulsive ritual. She walks the perimeter every 30 minutes to make manual observations, despite automated drone coverage.
notes.subject: Personal Documentation System
notes.context: Elena's unauthorized but meticulously maintained record-keeping practice

notes.text: The parent megacorporation that currently employs Elena as a contractor is the same corporate entity that owned the chemical processing plant where she previously worked. This corporation was responsible for: writing falsified incident reports after the tank rupture, causing Elena's flagged safety emails to 'disappear,' engineering her professional destruction while avoiding legal liability, and subsequently rehiring her under exploitative contractor terms after she became desperate. Elena views all corporate authority through the lens of this betrayal.
notes.subject: Parent Megacorporation

notes.text: Len has known Dylan Crace for a week, the time they've been assigned to monitor the rip in reality in these remote salt flats. Dylan said that he's an ex-military security contractor. He did convoy escort and asset recovery in disaster zones for subsidiaries of this same megacorp. He isn't here for money, or at least he said so: he's here because he thinks this post is history-level important. He actually asked for this assignment. Len thinks that corporate propaganda got him. Dylan talks. Won't shut up. That alone grates on Len, who's quiet. Dylan calls Len 'Amezua' professionally, but slips and calls her 'Elena' when he's stressed, which she hates because it sounds like ownership. She always answers 'Crace,' never 'Dylan,' because she will not give that ground. Corporate only provided Len with a pistol, but they geared Dylan Crace up with an assault rifle, due to his military training.
notes.subject: Dylan Crace
notes.context: the only other sentinel guarding the rip in reality
